p:
A consequence of rapid economic growth in China is a deterioration of air quality. An air pollution record was set in January 2013, with unprecedented large-scale haze lasting almost an entire month. During this so-called “airpocalypse” period, ~70% of the 74 major cities exceeded the daily PM 2.5 (particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 μm or less; see table S1 for a list of all acronyms) ambient air quality standard of China (75 μg m −3), with the maximum daily PM 2.5 reaching 766 μg m −3 and the monthly mean concentration reaching as high as 130 μg m −3 (
1 ). Exposure to such high PM concentrations endangers public health with increasing risks of cardiovascular and respiratory morbidity (
2 ,
3 ).
